This paper deals with the problem of cost sharing in ridesharing, which involves designing algorithms that allocate the cost of a shared ride among the passengers in a fair and efficient manner. This problem is a classic example of game theory, which falls under the category of cs.GT (Game Theory and Economics). The paper also proposes a new notion of fairness called sequential fairness, which involves sharing the benefits of ridesharing among the passengers in proportion to the inconvenience costs they suffer. This idea is related to the field of artificial intelligence (cs.AI), which deals with designing algorithms that mimic human decision-making. The paper also provides an exact characterization of all routes for which there exists some cost sharing scheme that is sequentially fair, which involves analyzing the structural properties of the problem. This analysis involves techniques from the field of data structures (cs.DS) and machine learning (cs.LG). Finally, the paper proposes new algorithmic problems related to sequential individual rationality and sequential fairness, which involve designing efficient algorithms for solving these problems. These problems fall under the category of social and information networks (cs.SI), which deals with analyzing the structure and dynamics of social networks.
